name: Riga
fun_fact: Fun fact: Riga's Central Market operates in five repurposed German Zeppelin hangars from World War I, making it one of the largest and most architecturally unique markets in Europe - and it's a UNESCO World Heritage Site alongside the Old Town.

hero_dishes.description: Latvia's national dish made with dried grey peas (similar to chickpeas in texture), crispy bacon, and caramelized onions. The peas are stewed until creamy and topped with crunchy speck.
hero_dishes.origin_story: Traditionally served at Christmas, this hearty peasant dish has been a Latvian staple for centuries. Grey peas are a heritage crop unique to the Baltic region, completely different from common green peas.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Folkklubs Ala Pagrabs (in an old wine cellar), Old Traditions Restaurant (VecƒÅs Tradƒ´cijas), LIDO Vƒìrmanƒ´tis

hero_dishes.name: Rupjmaize (Dark Rye Bread)
hero_dishes.description: Dense, slightly sweet dark rye bread with a deep, complex flavor. Often served with butter, local cheese, or honey.
hero_dishes.origin_story: Rye bread is sacred in Latvian culture, with traditions dating back over 1,000 years. The bread is made with a sourdough starter that families pass down through generations, and there's even a dessert version called rye bread pudding.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Folkklubs Ala Pagrabs (famous for rye bread pudding), Riga Central Market bakery stalls

hero_dishes.name: Sklandrausis
hero_dishes.description: Traditional Latvian rye pastry filled with a sweet mixture of mashed carrots and potatoes, seasoned with caraway seeds.
hero_dishes.origin_story: This ancient recipe from the Kurzeme region is so culturally significant that it's on Latvia's protected cultural heritage list. The unusual carrot-potato filling reflects the resourcefulness of Latvian peasants.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: LIDO restaurants, Riga Central Market, Rozengrais

hero_dishes.name: KarbonƒÅde (Latvian Pork Schnitzel)
hero_dishes.description: Breaded pork cutlet served with creamy mushroom sauce, typically accompanied by boiled potatoes and pickled vegetables.
hero_dishes.origin_story: A Soviet-era adaptation of the Austrian schnitzel that became distinctly Latvian through the addition of local forest mushroom sauce and traditional preparation methods.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Milda (Michelin Bib Gourmand), BaltƒÅ Kaza (White Goat), Old Traditions Restaurant

signature_drinks.name: Riga Black Balsam
signature_drinks.description: A 45% alcohol herbal liqueur with a complex, bittersweet flavor made from 24 different herbs, roots, and berries.
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Traditionally consumed as a shot or mixed with blackcurrant juice or coffee. Locals swear by it as a cure for colds and digestive issues. Often served at room temperature or warm in winter.

signature_drinks.name: Kvass
signature_drinks.description: Fermented rye bread drink with a slightly sour, malty taste and very low alcohol content.
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: A popular summer refreshment sold from street vendors. Locals drink it ice-cold, straight from the tap at markets and festivals.

food_culture_notes: Latvian cuisine emphasizes preserved foods - pickles, smoked fish, and fermented products are essential
Foraging culture is strong; mushrooms, berries, and wild herbs feature prominently in traditional dishes
The Soviet era influenced Latvian cuisine significantly, creating fusion dishes that are now considered traditional
Riga's Central Market is the beating heart of food culture - locals shop there daily for fresh, seasonal ingredients
